text:
ED LAVANDERA: If
the problem's not
right in front of their eyes--
JEFF POE: Right.

ED LAVANDERA: --then
it's easy to kind of push
to the back of your mind.
JEFF POE: It is easy.

It's easy to push
it to the side.

And then when everything that
happens is related to climate

change-- every storm you
get, every bad cold front,

it could be bad cold or
bad hot, either one--

you know, it's all
because of climate change.

You know, that's
what they tell you.
But it's always been that way.

You know, and
that's what gets me.
ED LAVANDERA: Right.

JEFF POE: Because,
you know, whether--

ED LAVANDERA: So that
makes you more skeptical.
JEFF POE: It does.

ED LAVANDERA: When every
little thing gets blamed on--
JEFF POE: Right, climate change.

I just-- you know,
it goes in one ear

and out the other
when I'm hearing that.

Because it's always
been that way.
- Yeah, we like him.
That's what we need.

ED LAVANDERA: Being someone
who's outdoors so much,
and you said you're at the--

how did you describe it--
being at the tip of the spear?
JEFF POE: Right

ED LAVANDERA: Do you feel
that just living down here

kind of gives you a
front row seat to the way
the environment changes?
JEFF POE: Yeah, it does.

You know, because the
environment affects me daily.

You know, everything I do
revolves around the weather.

ED LAVANDERA: How many
scientists or how much evidence

would I have to bring
down here to you

to convince you
that it's something
that needs to be addressed?

Or put it on your list
of top five concerns?

JEFF POE: Well,
as long as there's

people on the other
side, and as long

as there's an argument
about it, you know,
I don't see changing my mind.

You know, I don't think there's
anything that you could bring.

Because I mean, you can
always find somebody.

You know, I could
find the same thing.

You know, so as long as
things are the way they

are right now where
there's two sides to it,
you know, I don't--

well, I mean, you
could change my mind.

But I don't know
what it would take.
You want net?
- All right.
JEFF POE: Famous last words.

If somebody offers the net, you
always accept because of that.

Yeah, no, if you could
find me somebody that

says the exact percentage
of what we're causing,
I'd go with it.
ED LAVANDERA: Yup.

JEFF POE: But I don't
see anybody saying that.

And another thing I don't
see is I don't see anybody
talking about what's natural.

You know, like this
shoreline moving northward.

You know, you never hear
that on the news, you know,
or anywhere.

You never hear that
out of a politician.

They don't want to tell
you that because it

takes away from their narrative
that it's all caused by us.

If they were to say,
you know, this has
been going on for 20,000 years.
A speckled trout.
